you don't need to look beyond, last 10 years AMAZON CAPEX is around 150B, most of them as growth CAPEX and not maintenance CAPEX, so if you calculate FCF based on pure GAAP cash flow metrics (Operational cashflow - total CAPEX), you really get it wrong because the majority of that CAPEX is a reinvestment of cash that already generated, and if not decided to reinvest, it can be distributed among shareholder. In my mind, though GAAP cash flow is around 25B (2020) and  CAPEX 40B(2020), if you calculate what is growth bit in that CAPEX is and add it back to GAAP FCF you will get around 45B FCF(2020), and if you use this method to calculate AMZN future value conservatively (20-30 P/E and  10-30 YOY growth for next 10 years), you will see why amazon still trading at fair value territory. You can use the buffet(average depreciation for a long period like 20 yrs) or greenwood(Net PPE/Sales ) method to calculate maintenance CAPEX, but I personally take the average of both as they both are not 100% accurate.

Now do the same argument can be applied to a company like Tesla I would say no,  Tesla is most likely another CISCO, their CAPEX is very low 22B last 10 years, and they will not be able to scale as AMAZON did, or create a moat-like amazon did. 100 other car manufacturers will not let Tesla run as amazon did in the e-commerce space, due to obvious reasons.

@Sebastian Schmidt at Aktien-EXP I'm actually a bigger fan of an unknown management that performs well than a management that's in every magazine and does 'ok'.

In terms of valuation of NVR, to me it looks quite high, but the fundamentals are quite good: although declining the past 3 years it has an above average ROE compared to it's industry, they seem to be able to turn their investments into gross profit at a rate higher than their competitors, they have no notable debt (compared to their competitors one of the lowest). If you compare it to their cash at hand they almost have no actual debt. Their liquidation value is one the the highest (but that's because most of what's on their balance, is cash). 

In terms of price per revenue, yeah, that spiked quite a bit the last year, like a lot... certainly with their revenue clearly slowing down in growth. Price to revenue is almost double of what it has historically been... on the bright side: their cost of goods are fairly stable and have even come down the last few years (raising to an 70% gross profit margin, compared to a 65% 7 years ago). But even still: on a price per gross profit, the price almost doubled the last year. 
They seem to be doing well in optimizing the company: They brought down SG&A from as high as 60% 10 years ago to a low 30% today. Steady rising, but slowing down cash flow from operations, which is not ideal, but good enough. 
Just from the standpoint of free cash flow, they aren't highly overpriced. But also not cheap, certainly there's better deals on the market. Especially if you look international, but even domestic. 

The only thing you should look into is that they are losing ground to their competitors steadily over the last 5 years with about 1 to 0.5% a year. . This could be because they chose to grow slower compared to their competitors, so it's not necessarily a bad thing, but I'd look into that the most if I were you.
